awd_titl_txt: 2013 UNAVCO Community & Facility Bridge Proposal: Geodesy Revealing the Earth in Action

por.por_cntn:
UNAVCO is a non-profit, university-governed consortium that facilitates geoscience research and education using geodesy. UNAVCO supports a community that includes scientists affiliated with 106 US academic Member universities and 94 Associate Member institutions. This community is active and productive in many areas of Earth Science, including, but not limited to solid earth science, polar science, atmospheric sciences, hydrogeodesy, and climate science. UNAVCO has the unique and fundamental role of providing solid Earth and cryospheric scientists with free access to a pooled resource of geodetic technologies, instruments, equipment, data, technical support and collaboration. These resources enable fundamental Earth Science research to be conducted from the equator to the poles. UNAVCO-supported scientific research by the community has resulted in more than 6,000 peer-reviewed scholarly papers. UNAVCO also facilitated community collaborations via four Science Workshops during the award period.

UNAVCO provided two primary services: instrumentation and engineering services to Principal Investigators, and data services to the science community. UNAVCO supported over 300 research projects. The UNAVCO Data Center provides a secure, long-term archive for collected data along with tools that add value to the data and products in the archive. Data from 2,600+ permanent GPS stations worldwide are archived at UNAVCO and available to researchers and the public.

The UNAVCO Facility provided resources to EarthScope, an NSF program that deploys thousands of seismic, GPS, and other geophysical instruments to study the structure and evolution of the North American continent and the processes the cause earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. The UNAVCO Facility also provided services that complemented its work funded under a separate EarthScope award where UNAVCO maintained and operated the Plate Boundary Observatory (PBO). PBO includes a network of more than 1,100 permanent, continuous GPS stations and 78 borehole geophysics observing systems that span the US.  Observing stations are concentrated in the western United States – where deformation in response to earthquakes, fault motions, volcanoes, and seasonal loading of surface and ground water – is most prevalent.  Under the Facility award, UNAVCO provided EarthScope campaign support through testing, maintaining, improving, and shipping the GPS systems for EarthScope research projects, primarily related to PBO. UNAVCO provided oversight of the EarthScope geodetic imagery program, including the collection of airborne LiDAR topography data and development of a SAR data archive for interferometry analysis. With NASA funding, UNAVCO and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory manage the International Global Navigation Systems Satellite (GNSS) Service (IGS) Central Bureau and operates the NASA Global GNSS Network. 

UNAVCO supported development and testing of hardware, firmware and software including GPS receivers, antennas, data communications, power systems, and the development of new instrumentation. The Development and Testing Group conducted tests of real-time positioning algorithms and GNSS receiver performance under simulated earthquake conditions. Tests were conducted on a high-power commercial shaketable and later on a self-designed and built antenna actuator.  Participation in the West Coast Real-Time working group led by the U.S. Geological Survey is ongoing.
